data

Interface DoubleMatrixInterface

  • All Known Subinterfaces:
    View
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractViewImplementation, AddLabelsView, AddRGBView, ArrayListView, CloneView, DoubleArrayView, DoubleMatrixView, ExampleFilter, FeatureFilter, Features, FeatureWeightsView, FileView, MergeExamplesView, MergeFeaturesView, NormView, SpecialFeatures, TrainView, Transpose

    public interface DoubleMatrixInterface
    The DoubleMatrixInterface represents a two-dimensional double matrix. Any implementing class can be accessed as a getNumberOfRows x getNumberOfColumns matrix. For example, any View implements this interface, but in addition has meta information.
    Author:
    pwelke

    • Method Summary

      Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      double get(int i, int j)
      Returns the value of feature j in the i'th example.
      int getNumberOfColumns()
      Returns the number of features in this view of the data.
      int getNumberOfExamples()
      Returns the number of examples in this view of the data.
      double[][] materialize()
      Return all data visible in this view as a double[][] array.
      double[] materializeExample(int i)
      Return example i as a double array.
      double[][] materializeExamples(int[] i)
      Return examples i as a double array.
      double[] materializeFeature(int j)
      Return the values of feature j in all examples as a double array.
      double[][] materializeFeatureExamples(int[] i, int[] j)
      Return examples i and features j as a double array Conventionally, the array is expected to be an independent copy.
      double[][] materializeFeatures(int[] j)
      Return the values of features j in all examples as a double array.
      void materializeMinMaxValue()
      calculate min and max value of data
      void materializeXYDimension()
      calculate x and y dimension of data

      • materializeFeature

        double[] materializeFeature(int j)
        Return the values of feature j in all examples as a double array. Conventionally, the array is expected to be an independent copy. I.e. changing the i'th value in the returned array does not change the value returned by get(i,j) in the original view.
        Parameters:
        j -
        Returns:

      • materializeFeatures

        double[][] materializeFeatures(int[] j)
        Return the values of features j in all examples as a double array. Conventionally, the array is expected to be an independent copy. I.e. changing the i'th value in the returned array does not change the value returned by get(i,j) in the original view.
        Parameters:
        j -
        Returns:

        Parameters:
        j -
        Returns:

      • materialize

        double[][] materialize()
        Return all data visible in this view as a double[][] array. Conventionally, the array is expected to be an independent copy. I.e. changing the [i][j]'th value in the returned array does not change the value returned by get(i,j) in the original view.
        Returns:

      • materializeFeatureExamples

        double[][] materializeFeatureExamples(int[] i,
                                    int[] j)
        Return examples i and features j as a double array Conventionally, the array is expected to be an independent copy. I.e. changing the [i][j]'th value in the returned array does not change the value returned by get(i,j) in the original view.
        Returns:
